However, we just had one of the worst services today. We came in when the restaurant was completely empty. The waiters were just standing around and chatting. It took them 10 minutes to notice us, and we had to ask for the water. After they brought the food, our waiter never came back again. I'm not sure if he is just young or lack the experience, but if you have the time to stand there and stare into space the whole time, I'm sure you can spare one minute to ask us if we need anything just once. My boyfriend and I are generous tippers but not this time.

This is by far one of the best Chinese restaurants that I've been to in the area. We had the dry pot, soup dumplings, and cauliflower dish. They have a decent menu to pick from. They also sale a la mousse bakery and king fu tea there too. Makes you think if the owners are related... I like the easily payment system, it's like how China with WeChat. Next Tim I'll be back for other dish.
Bai Wei has very nice and patient servers and the food they serve are very good as well. Would highly recommend it.

Our regular place closes at 8 pm now so we needed to break out of our routine at 8:15 pm on a Sunday night and so glad that we did. Have been going by Bai Wei for a while and it's always crowded - we went for the first time tonight. Outdoor seating, plenty of space between the tables. Food was amazing and so different than what we get at our usual haunts. Had pork soup dumplings, shredded duck with Peking sauce and Lamb/Cumin dry pot. All really delicious - clean flavors, not greasy at all. We will definitely be back!

We dropped by now that outside eating is up and running for a quick Sunday lunch. There was plenty of seating about 1:30 when we arrived. Service was prompt and friendly given the need for masks and gloves. Food was a little slow but not so much as to be annoying. Everything arrived hot and tasty. 

Be aware that they're presently cash only but if you forget there are plenty of ATMs in the area

Perfect for cold weather! We chose the " stinky pot " consist off beef and tofu , the noodle dishes are good too . Can see why they are busy. Server was very nice and accommodating. Only thing is that they only take cash , might be inconvenient for some and restricted some guests who might've order more

Bai Wei has pretty good service, the people there are very nice. I spoke in Chinese, so I'm not really sure how fluent anyone's English was. The interior is beautiful! It's a very clean looking place. The portions are normal sized. The food is pretty good in general. It's just like any basic Chinese restaurant. I came here on a chilly March evening for dinner because I was in the area. There doesn't seem to be much heat, so I had to keep my coat on. The food came a little slow, but it was also quite busy, so that was fine. Another thing I like about this place is that it is well lit, so if your coming here with a group, it's perfect!

I came here with my family for dinner. 
The food was incredible, the fish and pork are so delicious. We enjoyed the atmosphere a lot. The decoration in this place is very stylish and very clean.  The service is great, the waiters are very helpful and friendly. They always come checking on us at the right time and all smiling.  We had a great time!

My friend and her boyfriend claim they visit here twice every weekend so I had to give it a try. Situated on the outskirts of philly chinatown, I completely missed this location the past times I visited Philly . 

We got the sizzling Japanese tofu with shrimp, beef in spicy chili sauce, and the chinese water spinach. Let's say I now see the reason why they like this place so much.

First of all I have not yet found any other place that serves Japanese tofu in either Philly or DC, and it was one of my favorite childhood dish. Seeing the sizzling Japanese tofu on the menu already hyped me up, and I was definitely not disappointed by the taste of it either. It definitely brought back memories of when I had this in China.

The beef in spicy chili sauce was perfectly within my spice tolerance range. The beef slices were really tender and easy to chew, and the flavor of the sauce really seeped in as well. I even enjoyed eating the bean sprouts on the bottom. Personally I do wish this dish was less salty, especially for this genre of Sichuan spice dish. 

The competition for authentic chinese food in Philly Chinatown is fierce, but I would still recommend giving it a try. It definitely checked all the checkmarks for a tasty Sichuan meal for me.

Sensational service coupled by solid food

Service:

Went on a Saturday, and it was quite busy. With a reservation, though, we were seated in about 5 mins, although there was a wait to the door. 

We ordered the food swiftly as we were in a bit of a rush. They didn't disappoint. It felt like a bit of a procession with the food just perpetually coming out in what was seemingly perfectly spaced intervals. We were in and out in 35 minutes 

Food:
Scallion pancake- unlike your conventionally doughy, decadent scallion pancake you get, this was cracker thin, buttery, with a delightful crisp.

Black truffle soup dumplings- they were ok. The texture of the actual dumpling was adequate, being robust enough to encase the insides safely. The porky soup of the dumpling, though, was lacking that rich umami flavor I long for in a soup dumpling, rendering this dish inert for me.

Black truffle, beef fried rice- I can see why there is some fanfare for this dish. With the truffle, it adds this mystical flavor profile that I can't really pinpoint, but is tantalizingly yummy. 


In actuality, I'd give them a 4.5. But I'll give them the benefit and knock them up to 5

I love love love this place! They have the best shrimp fried rice in the city. Everything I get from here is always tasty. Soup dumplings are delicious as well. I try to try something new every time i come here. I definitely recommend it! Lunch, dinner, with family, friends or by yourself!

There's like, a 20% surcharge on their grubhub prices which I didn't realize was there until I dined in last week for the first time, so I recommend NOT USING GRUBHUB for Bai Wei. Even for a cash/venmo only restaurant, 20% is a little insane. A dish I paid $18 for on grubhub was only $15 on the menu, and the fish I got on Wednesday that cost me $16 at the restaurant is listed at $20 on grubhub! And that's not counting if you then pay for delivery and tip your delivery driver.

But anyway, on to the food. The first time I got sizzling Japanese tofu and shrimp off grubhub, it looked nothing like another reviewer's picture, the shrimp were tiny "medium" sized shrimp barely the size of a nickel (why grocery stores call those medium shrimp and then have to go up to large, extra large, and then jumbo, I'll never understand, marketing, I guess), there were some diced carrots and onions which were undercooked, and the entire dish was orange and tasted of, what I guess I'd call "shrimp blood". Now, my mom uses fresh head-on shrimp in her pork steamed buns  and it's great, but when she tried to do the same trying out a chiang fun recipe, it was an orange disaster. In a dish that's more mild such as tofu, using head-on shrimp is more disaster territory than a good idea, just stick with headless frozen shrimp please. Japanese tofu is always tasty though, no matter how bad you screw up the rest of the dish, so I still ate the whole thing.

But because TT Skewer and I are forever starcrossed (that's another story), I decided to give Bai Wei another chance, and I'm glad I did (and not just because I caught the grubhub thing). I got fish fillet in spicy sauce (水煮鱼 and the server had to verify I wanted the spicy dish and not literally boiled fish, which was topkek). And now, the only restaurant I've ever had this at served it with tofu and peanuts which is about as far from traditional as you can get, so my perception of this dish is way out of whack. Bai Wei does it more typically with cabbage and bean sprouts and it was equally good and I felt healthy getting some vegetables in.

The server did not stop by at all during my meal because I was all set with a gigantic pot of tea and it's typical in China to flag down waiters rather than wait for them to come to you (my parents HATE it when servers pop by to ask how we're doing), but within a few minutes of finishing eating and pulling out my phone, a server came by to ask if I was finished, so I assume they're relatively attentive and quick to respond, so just don't be shy you'll be fine at Bai Wei. 

The white furniture and elevated dining area is also pretty cute, so I'd dine in again sometime, just not grubhub, never mix grubhub and this place.

Wow I cannot believe how bad the food was.  I leave a LOT of room for errors or issues these days, but this was horrendous. 
The scallion pancakes were drenched in oil. So greasy. 
The beef dumplings had a really gross and overcooked filling.  I had one and had to chuck it. 
The soup dumplings had absolutely no soup. Not even an exaggeration. 
The dan dan noodles were absolutely not authentic (or even mildly tasty). The noodles they use are like spaghetti noodles. And the sauce doesnt taste like anything but peppers.
Edamame was old and gross. 
The only good thing was the lychee tea. 
I really don't think anyone should eat here.

I went with about 25 people for a club event and they accommodated us in their back room. The service was excellent and the food was abundant. Preferred a little bit more flavor but everything was very good and I will definitely go back. Again everyone there was super nice.
I went there to try its spicy fish. After I ordered the fish, I waited for close to an hour,  but only to learn that they did not place my order yet, a complete waste of my time.
It's early delivery and it's very nice to have paper note in the bag for ordering a rice separately. Thanks for the note. It's very good reaction and proactivity.

Omg! I read the reviews on here and they were correct! I got the crispy fried fish and the dice chicken and the plum spare ribs. Also the soup dumplings. They had to bring us another table because we ordered so much for our table.

The food did not disappoint! The place was packed on a Saturday night. But our wait was only about 15 minutes. Service was good for being so busy.

I'm still thinking of the crispy fish days later.

The place is super nice. It's bright modern and food is delicious. The wait staff was diligently working with the Christmas Eve rush. They were attentive despite the place being packed. We ordered the pork and crab soup dumplings, spicy fish filets, shrimp with walnut and mayo sauce and our dessert called the Tangerine which looked like it came out of a Michelin Star restaurant it was that pretty. The only down side of this establishment is that they only accept cash or Venmo. So keep that in mind. It's also BYOB.

I've worked in the restaurant industry for 7 years, so I'm pretty forgiving when it comes to mistakes, but my experience here was so bad I actually made an account to share what happened.
Our order arrived by delivery on time. However the bag was absolutely COVERED in red oil, and 2 of the items we ordered were not delivered.  
I called the restaurant to let them know about the missing items.  I was told bluntly that the mistake happened because they were busy, and that they were also too busy to deliver the rest of the order.  I asked, "Is there anything you can do to make this right?"  And was told, "No."
So now I'm on here writing this review and talking to my credit card company.
Mistakes happen, but that type of terrible customer service is just wrong.

This restaurant used to be Sakura Mandarin but just underwent renovations. I've been to Sakura a few times before so I was excited to check this place out once it reopened.
The interior is totally revamped with a new drink/dessert menu but I can't say that I was impressed by the food. We ordered the chili pepper chicken off the specials and the flavor was overpoweringly spicy with no complexity. It was definitely not worth the price it was billed. The beef pancake appetizer was not what I expected. Instead of scallion pancake around the beef it was literally a patty bun. The stir fried udon with pork was also lackluster.
I was honestly disappointed by the whole meal. Plus it's cash only. There are way better options for eating out in Chinatown.
One of our favorite place to go eat in Philly. Excellent scallion pancakes, soup and pan fried dumplings. Great lunch specials during weekdays.

I love the food at Bei Wei! It's the ONLY Chinese food I will eat & yes, worth the drive to Chinatown! Jack & staff are SUPER nice & desserts are from A La Mousse...around the corner & other location, with Anna, Jacks wife, as head pastry chef...high end, delicious ingredients...just like Bei Wei...

I really enjoyed bai wei! First things first, the interior of this restaurant is very clean and modern. The menu is a little pricier than what you usually see around Chinatown but for the atmosphere it's worth it! I got to try out the black truffle soup dumplings which were alright but cool to try. We also sampled the tangerine cheese cake and mango mousse cake. The mango cake was really great and unique but the tangerine cheesecake was not as great. I definitely think this place is worth checking out!

I hate being that person on here because I understand restaurants might still be struggling with staffing still with the ongoing pandemic, but I was so excited to try this place after seeing good reviews and it was truly very disappointing :( I love Asian food and restaurants so I have been trying to tackle the dim sum spots in the city , so I have a few good ones to compare it to!

I ordered a few items to try for the first time of things that you can really go wrong with at a decent dim sum spot usually - scallion pancakes, edamame, wonton soup, and steamed and pan seared pork soup dumplings. This is the first time I've ever been unhappy with every single thing I tried at a restaurant unfortunately....the edamame was the best part and even that was lacking salt. The scallions pancakes were soaked in oil and pretty chewy. The wontons in the soup were pretty small and just tasted off. And both orders of soup dumplings had 0 soup in them and they were undercooked :/ 

Maybe my experience was slightly different than dining in since I ordered delivery - but that didn't affect that the overall taste and flavors, quality, and execution of the food preparation that was more than lacking. I don't think I'd even be willing to give this place another chance since there are way better options in Philly.

Not pleased at all... my husband  & I are Dim Sum hopping today.  This is the three place we stopped at!! Second was not worth mentioning... the food is not good at this location. -although, my husband loved the wonton soup! I found the spring rolls bland with little favor. Same for the Pork Wonton in Chili Sauce. 
Staff is neither friendly nor unfriendly, I am just not comfortable here.

One of my favorite Chinese restaurant in the Philly area. They have a very modern-esque vibe to the place and there's plenty of seating. The only thing that some people may not like is that they only accept cash, venmo or alipay. For me it's never been an issue, because I am a big venmo person, but this may be a turn off for some. 

I have been to Bai Wei several times at this point and I have never ordered anything that I have disliked. The food always comes out hot and fresh and this is also one of the places I always bring friends to if they've never tried "real Asian" food before. 

Service has always been pretty good, however nothing too memorable. I have always had speedy and good service while I have eaten here. I also like how they partner up with A La Mousse for their desserts, you can sometimes see the desserts at the counter window, but if they don't have what you want A La Mousse is right around the corner not even a minute walk away.

---SAFETY CONCERN---
 There is a huge fly in fried chicken wings.  Gross... 

Customer care was like hell. No apologies from the business. 

Terrible experience
LOVE this place! One of my favorites for dumplings in the city. Pork soup dumplings are a must here. Casual, bright setting with lots of windows.
Service was absolutely great but the food was ok. I was really hoping to love it and have a new spot to go to on rotation.

It's a decent option in Chinatown if you are looking for a "generalist" type fare as they serve Szechuan, Shanghai, Taiwan, and some Cantonese dishes.  I would say that the quality is just okay.  The variety is the draw here and they also offer a 10% Yelp check-in offer.  The staff are fiendly but they seem very rushed as it was quite busy and there were only 2-3 waiters in the entire restaurant serving all the tables and taking takeout orders as well. 

Cash and Venmo only!

A recap of the dishes:
1. Sweet osmanthus and sesame mochi dumpling soup: This was perfectly light, sweet, and refreshing with thin shreds of osmanthus and egg whites.  The dumplings were fluffy and filled with sesame.  They are smaller than normal but each was  perfectly balanced bite of filling to shell.
2. Crabmeat and pork soup dumplings: These were kind of meh with a thick shell and barely any soup and filling.  Maybe it was an off-day but I would suggest the other pan-fried options instead.
3. Pan Fried buns: These were better than the soup dumplings but the filling was pretty sparse and definitely could have been more generous in portion.  4. Pan fried dumplings: These were solid with a plump, juicy filling and nicely crispy pan fried shell.
5. Chive buns: Nice nd crispy with a flavorful egg and chive filling.  The only thing that would have made them better would have been some vemicelli inside but pretty solid overall.
6. Stir-fried clams: Pretty flavorful clams albeit small ones.  It's a bit on the salty side but still pretty solid.
7. Plum spare ribs: Fried sweet spareribs with sweet plums.  Overall, a nice appetizer-sized option (the ribs are small).  The meat is flavorful and pretty tender but the dish itself is not very filling so this is more of a starter vs an actual main entree.
8. Seafood tofu casserole: Mostly light silkn tofu with 3 prawns, some fishballs, and 3 pieces of surimi.  This is very light but the seafood portion was tiny.  The nice part is that it isn't oily at all but it's definitely not your traditional seafood hot pot.
9. Seafood udon: Stir fried udon with seafood in a traditional brown oyster-soy.  This was pretty standard but it was branded as a Shanghai stir fried thick noodle and it resembled more of a Japanese stir-fried udon.  It was just okay but a bit salty.
10. Marinated sliced roast beef: This was just okay.  The beef was tender but slightly dry and didn't have that sweet and savaory marinade that is the hallmark of the 5-spice Shanghainese beef.
11. Seasonal stir-fried vegetables: This was light and refeshing and surprisngly one of the best dishes with sliced lotus, cauliflower, broccoli, snow peas, mushrooms, woodear, carrots, and asparagus.  There was just a very slight coagulation of the corn starch thickener on some pieces but they were very busy tonight and likely understaffed in the kitchen so they were likely making this in a rush.

Ordered takeout from Bai Wei tonight. First time I've ordered from here and was really happy I did. Went with the General Tso, Chicken Pad Thai, Pork Fried Rice, Scallion Pancake, and Spring Rolls. Everything was awesome! Scallion Pancake was the highlight for me...love those suckers! Pork Fried Rice was awesome as well. Will be ordering from here again.

I have ordered from Bai Wei for at least 20 times, but now, I really worry about their food health problem, especially during COVID-19, we have no idea about how they cook, pack, and deliver. In the last order, I found a feather in the box. I contacted the restaurant, they claimed that "there is no way that a feather could exist in our food", and they only willing to return 1/4 of the dish's price. That's almost a humiliation and a representative of how they ignore their food health problem.

My friend and I got the boiled seafood with Alaskan crab. She got shrimp as her second seafood and I got crawfish. My crab was amazing, big chunks I could pull out all in one piece. I loved the butter sauce with just a hint of spice. They also put corn on the cob and potatoes in the butter sauce. It's so good. The staff were all masked and gloved and we were given sanitary wipes and plastic gloves to eat with. Also, the outdoor seating area was very cute, with sunflowers and string lights.

My bf and I ate here for the first time the other night and wow! We tried to come back for dinner the very next day (Memorial Day) but they were closed. It was that good we tried to eat here two nights in a row. The restaurant is very big and clean inside. Staff was friendly and quick with the food. We ordered the scallion pancake, steamed crabmeat and pork Soup dumpling, and drunken noodle with shrimp. Everything was absolutely amazing! My boyfriend was obsessed with the drunken noodle and I'm tied between the noodle and soup dumplings. The total was $25, which was mind blowing because it came with a lot of food. Check this place out!!

"Good things come to those who wait" (so they say). Bai Wei has been saved in my collections for a while now & I'm glad to say I finally made my way here (though it wasn't planned)!

Arrived shortly before closing and although you can tell they were preparing for that, the waiter was super nice and took his time attending to my guest & I. 

We ordered the Shrimp & Vegetables dumplings along with two separate orders of fried rice. Even though I am not a beef fried rice fan, I decided to try their Beef Fried Rice with Black Truffle. TBH! The idea of truffle in fried rice did not sound all that appealing, but since the waiter recommended it I decided to go with his suggestion. Thank God! Because, WOW! I have never had anything like it. If you ever get a chance to visit Ba Wei, I would highly suggest trying this dish out. 
The dumplings were also pretty good. 

Fairly priced, located in Chinatown and the decor is super chic and modern. Would definitely recommend (However, bring cash because they were not taking cards at the time.)

Originally the Sakura restaurant, same location with an updated menu.

We had an take out order.  Overall taste is good on couple of them and average for the rest.  They don't accept credit cards, so cash (or some Chinese payment like wechat pay, etc).  One of the fish dish we ordered looks like an appetizer size, the container is only like half full.  And even though we ordered 6 full dishes, there is no white rice; the server told me they never include rice (unless you pay for it); this is kind of strange, I haven't been to any Chinese restaurant that does that.  

On the pro side, the service is pretty fast; my order is ready within 20 minutes and they texted me to pick up.

We have eaten here many many times- never disappointed and actually every single
Thing we have ordered has been excellent. Fried fish. Fried truffle rice. Soup dumplings. Cabbage. On and on and on. We have some take out and eat in and eating in is definitely much better

This is a great lunch spot with quick service and tasty soup dumplings! Just one star short of five because the pork inside the pork soup dumplings were a tad bit undercooked. The crabmeat dumplings were excellent though. I don't know exactly what kind of sauce is given to use with the soup dumpling, but it has a nice citrus taste to it (reminded me a lot of Japanese ponzu).
20/10 recommend! This place is amazing everything is great be sure to try the pork wonton in chili oil and braised pork noodle soup!
Food was great but the service was ok. If you're looking for some good Szechuan food, you can check this place out.

overall, definitely satisfied with the experience. my boyfriend and i originally intended to dine at dim sum garden down the street, but the line was out the door, so we stopped by bai wei. the food was pretty good, but the only payment options they accept are cash and venmo. we got the beef pan fried and pork steamed soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, and scallion beef, which were all tasty.

We were greeted warmly and promptly. Despite being packed, our waiter provided water and took our order within 5 minutes. Our triple delight and beef in chili sauce were fabulous with the lovely Sichuan pepper taking front and center in the savory beef dish. My son cleaned his plate of triple delight. I would definitely recommend and look forward to dining here again upon my return to Philedelphia.
I don't understand why they don't give rice with any dishes for takeout and no utensils How do I eat mapo tofu without rice....

We really enjoyed the dumplings from Bai Wei. We ordered delivery through caviar and was very pleasantly surprised by the quality of the soup dumplings and pan-fried dumplings! Will certainly order again!

My wife and I came in evening time around 5:30 and it wasn't overly packed. We got seated right away which was nice. I had to take away 2 stars because the servers took awhile to come take our orders (about 10 mins). We made eye contact with them but they just ignored us. When we finally ordered, we also wanted to order Spicy stir fry bowl which requires a separate menu paper to fill in what we want in it. They handed us that paper but it took another 10 minutes for them to come pick it up. I had to wave them down to get their attention. When we got our orders, it took another while to get the stir fry bowl and by that time, our other main dishes were done. 

Sadly, the spicy stir fry bowl wasn't what it used to be when the restaurant used to be called Sakura. 

The crab soup dumplings were good though. 

Only complaint is slow service even though it wasn't overly busy and they had a good handful of servers around.

Pretty Average, but That's Okay

We dined in at Bai Wei and they do a pretty good job of following safety protocols. 

That being said, much of the food we ordered was over flavored. I know this sounds ridiculous to say but there is such thing as too much spice. The Tofu soup was good initially, but there was way too much ginger in it. The Chinese Sausage with Leeks was borderline inedible due to how salty it was. It was so salty that we packed about 3/4 of it to go and washed it with water at home to eat it so we didn't waste any food. The only thing we really enjoyed was the cold beef dish that was actually pretty good. 

I do want to compliment them on their service. The key to hospitality isn't the food, though it's a key component obviously, it's how an establishment treats their patrons and this place does a wonderful job. We'd go back on this alone and try some other dishes.

Overall, okay food with great service considering they seemed like they were short staffed for obvious reasons. We still loved the night out because no one should take that for granted anymore.

Already came back to this establishment and left very happy and satisfied. My bf and I wanted to try something different since the menu is pretty big. Everything we ate tonight was delicious, but the food we ordered the first time was way better. Tonight we ordered the pork wonton in chili oil, steamed shrimp and vegetable dumplings, sautéed seafood noodles and diced chicken w/hot pepper. The pork wonton was good, but the chili oil wasn't what we expected. It had a nice kick to it and also a strong peanut taste. The sauce was good and I wish I could've saved some because it would've been good with noodles, rice or anything really. Strong peanut taste so if you're not about it maybe skip this dish. We both agreed that the shrimp and vegetable dumplings was the best thing we had tonight. It was so good!! Sautéed seafood noodles was nice because they were very generous with the assortment of seafood, BUT drunken noodles was 100% better. Seafood noodles were very wet drenched in sauce and was nothing mind blowing. The drunken noodles w/shrimp was out of this world and we also just prefer the wide noodles. Diced chicken was good, but also wasn't something we expected. It was a bit overpriced compared to everything else on their menu. $14 for the entree and 50% was all hot pepper flakes and 50% was small fried popcorn chicken. Tasty but we both dipped it in the dumpling sauce because it was fried and needed a tad bit more flavor. Everything was still delicious, but the food we ordered the first time was way better. Will definitely come back again to try more items. This place is byo so don't forget to bring some drinks!

Waiter was friendly, quick service, and checked in a few times. Food isn't that spicy, so if you can't tolerate it then nothing to worry about. One of the best authentic Chinese food places in Chinatown Philly.

Bai Wei, previously Sakura popped up as one of the RESTAURANT WEEK options this winter. Bai Wei's restaurant week menu offered three courses plus dessert but we decided to order a la carte. The appetizers - pork soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, chicken in diced red pepper, the typical Chinese staples were decent, nothing out of the ordinary but the entrees truly sets them apart from other Chinatown haunts. With a terrific range of options, we got to experience a great range of Chinese food from Shanghai to Sichuan and more. 

The fish filet with peppercorn was one of the best fish dishes I've had in a while. The smelly pot with chicken and sichuan sauce scores high on presentation and taste.  The dish has 'smelly' tofu, hence the name. You can choose to order this with less spicy sauces if you have a low tolerance for spice. The Japanese tofu and shrimp is another standout. The food is authentic, there are dozens of options, the portion sizes are huge and the experience in the end was very gratifying. The service was not quite at the same level but on this day, thus turned out to be a minor glitch in a hugely satisfying experience.

We were excited to visit because we had terrific dumpling in the past .. especially the soup dumplings ... well that was not what we received ... soup dumplings couldn't be any drier and on top of that they had holes all over them !! we asked one of the servers what happened ... he gave us a BC story saying that the soup dumpling had soup but they only put a tiny bit now ... LMAO ... really !! That's the story your going to give us ... it was disappointing.

I love nearly everything on their menu... and by this point I've nearly had everything on the menu!  I usually visit with a friend or two, but finally attended with a small crowd this weekend.  After another excellent experience, I wanted to get a review in.

Bai Wei offers a selection of Szechuan and Dim Sum.  While the dumpling and dim sum selection is limited, what they have is amazing.  Of course I'm going to tell you to get the crab and pork soup dumplings!

On the Szechuan side, you have all sorts of dry pot, stir fry, and pepper based dishes.  My top recommendation is the Lamb (or Beef) Cilantro. It was a hit for our group of six this weekend.  A dish I was surprised I loved so much was their assorted mushrooms.  The cumin dry pot is tasty and not as spicy as I suspected it would be and the eggplant is another solid order, especially for vegetarians. 

Service is polite and quick.  Since Bai Wei is also a BYO, they won't rush you out as you relax to finish whatever it is that we brought.  Worth noting, they only accept cash or venmo!

Excellent takeout, inspired by Craig Laban's Instagram on Christmas. Got the assorted mushrooms dry pot (cut the heat on everything else and really good), diced chicken with hot pepper, and shredded pork in garlic sauce (which comes with a different kind of mushroom). Plenty for 2; only didn't realize I needed to order rice separately.

This has become a take out staple for me. 
The scallion pancakes are a must. The crispy and spicy fish filet still show up at my house mostly crispy.  It's got that nice numb at the end spice!
The soup dumplings, while tasty, tend to travel less well. 
The beef and bean curd casserole was overly greasy but the flavors are amazing.

Definitely give this place a try.
The dishes are delicious, but only cash is required, and an 18% tip is forcibly charged on the bill during lunch time.

Their soup dumplings were ok. Tea pots are a definite with the fresh tea leaves. The only option for our dumplings & soup dumplings was the balsamic dip which was over powering and only took away from the dumplings. No soy or chili pepper oil was available which was a let down because the soup dumplings needed it. Service was really slow, but like most places they appear to be understaffed. The ambience is nice, staff was pleasant and food was appealing to the eye. Cash or Venmo ONLY.

the food is very good and authentic, especially the soup dumplings and spicy cucumber. i've been here about 5 times and they've been very consistent except for once when we ordered a serving of pork soup dumplings and every single on was broken. they still tasted good however i would definitely come back.

It was alright. Long-ish wait for two simple dishes, but the food was alright by my standards. The atmosphere was a bit weird - modern, but with a weird and dark colored/classic art mural wall with the modern white renovations. Servers were the usual you find in Chinatown - decent.

I was out with a friend the other day, trying to find a new place to eat at when the bears outside caught my eye. We ordered the House Special Smelly Pot with Chicken (Schechuan Spicy) and the Beef Stew & Dry Bean Curd Casserole.

The chicken was cooked really well, and it was very flavorful. However, we were late to realize that the Smelly Pot had stinky tofu in it which contaminated the whole dish (both of us do not like stinky tofu). The Beef Stew & Dry Bean Curd Casserole was also pretty good and tasted exactly as I expected. 

Overall, I would come back to try other dishes (but will never order the Smelly Pot again).

Also, it is good to note that this place is CASH ONLY (or Venmo).

We've passed Bai Wei/Sakura hundreds of times and never wanted to check it out. This last weekend though, we decided to give it a shot.

Sadly, our preconceived notions of the restaurant was confirmed. Subpar food at high prices. We ordered the marinated duck, the House Special Spicy bowl and the mushroom dry pot.

The food was bland and the portions were on the smaller side for the prices they were charging. I was also annoyed that there were no variety in the mushroom dry pot. There was only one type of mushrooms stir fried, and not the quality kind.

On top of that, you have to pay for rice?!?!? Never have I eaten in a restaurant in Chinatown where I have to pay for rice. Rice is  FREE when you buy dinner from a restaurant!

Do yourself a favor and skip this place. There are plenty of better options not far from Bai Wei.

Came here for Saturday dinner. When we were done, this place was packed.

Ordered the soup dumplings with black truffle. Love it! A lot of soup inside!

Also love the seafood tofu soup. Very fresh and a lot of seafood too!

The spicy chicken was just okay. Not the usual Chinese style, but more Americanized... The chicken had too much flour on the outside that you can barely taste the chicken...

Took my grandma out for an early thanksgiving dinner. She really liked the dark brown sugar bubble tea. She noticed the quality in the tea right away. She doesn't eat anything spicy but for the food we got, it was suitable for her taste. I feel this restaurant is for everyone. People who like spicy, don't like spicy, people who likes sweets and soup dumplings. This place is a must go!
Very authentic Chinese food. Love it.i will recommend friends to this place. The favorite one is steamed bum

Seriously delicious. I've never had dim sum and this place was the best place to give it a try! On their menu there is pictures with pretty much every type of what that food looks like - which is super helpful when you're a newby like me. Clean and inviting environment.

If you've ever had quality Asian food, this place is a big disappointment. The pan fried pork soup dumplings came out so quick. It wasn't even hot. There was so soup in it. It tastes like it's been sitting out for awhile and all the soup got absorbed into the bun. Their main dishes don't even come with rice. There's a separate charge for white rice. Their spicy fried fish is literally seasoned with taco seasoning. I would never come here again. I only came because all the other restaurants had long lines and this one didn't. Now I know why.

This place was great! My family loves the dim sum and everything we ordered was delicious! They accommodated our large party on a busy weekend without any issues and provided friendly, attentive service!

I love the fact that Chinatown Philly is updating the dining scene with new regional Chinese cuisine-- the menu here has some interesting dishes. 

I started with rose tea with foam. I'm not sure how they make their tea, but it was really really strong rose flavor--very unpleasant because it didn't taste natural. It tasted like potpourri. I had to add water to make it enjoyable. Rose tea should have a nice smooth rose flavor!!! 

Soup dumplings. I normally don't order this and restaurants that don't specialize in it. The crab and pork ones were cheap so I tried it out. These were ok. Good amount of crab compared to other places. The soup wasn't too flavorful and the dumpling skin was somewhat thick. 

I ordered a noodle with pork sauce. Sometimes this dish gets bad translations so you might get something different than expected... This was one of the times. I thought it would be Zha Jiang Mian, but I think they served me Dan Dan noodles. It had a strong sesame seed/peanut taste so that's why I think it was Dan Dan noodles. Portion was good, but if this was considered Dan Dan noodles, it lacked flavor. 

Ordered a fried chicken with chili. I forget the name. This was pretty good. I would order this again. 
 
Food took awhile which was fine bc it was soft opening. The soup dumplings I figure would take the longest but that came out first. The noodles took a long time to come out, so that's why I think they served me Dan Dan noodles and not Zha Jiang Mian. However, if I'm wrong, please let me know! 

On food and service, I would rate it 3 stars. It was just ok. Im talking away 1 star for something that shouldn't have happened. 

The restaurant had about 6 tables full. A server was moving plates/napkin/chopsticks to make room for another table. She DROPS the chopsticks on the floor. She picks it up and places it back on the table. .  

I'm Asian so I'm not usually bothered by this stuff but for a new restaurant to do this IN FRONT of people eating is not good. If we were in Asia, that's culturally acceptable, but in America, we should have better standards. I'm stating this so the owner can train the staff better. 

I'll visit again, bc they had some interesting looking dishes that other restaurants don't have.
